required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021

clinical_study.brief_title: Improving Asthma Care Together (IMPACT): A Shared Management Pilot Study
clinical_study.official_title: Improving Asthma Care Together (IMPACT): A Shared Management Pilot Study for Children With Asthma and Their Parents

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to iteratively develop, refine and test the Improving Asthma Care Together (IMPACT) Intervention for school-age children (7-11 years) with persistent asthma and their parents.

detailed_description.textblock:
Asthma is one of the most common chronic conditions of childhood, affecting over six million US children. Asthma treatment relies on self-management including symptom monitoring and response, trigger avoidance, and timely and appropriate medication use. Unfortunately, fewer than 50% of children with asthma are adherent to asthma treatment regimens, leading to increased disease morbidity and mortality and potentially irreversible airway damage.
Children with asthma are missing a voice in their own care. The school-age years (7-11) represent a natural transition in asthma management, as children must assume some responsibility for asthma-related care while they spend increasing time away from parents at school and other extracurricular activities. Yet, existing interventions focus on parents alone and use prescriptive approaches, telling the parent what to "do" to the child to manage their asthma. As a result, current strategies are failing to provide children with asthma and their families the tools they need to manage asthma successfully within the realities of their daily lives.
Using a Human-Centered Design (HCD) framework, the investigators co-designed a tailored asthma shared management mobile health application that pairs the parent and child together as a team and facilitates the intentional transition of some asthma management to the child. The hypothesis is that by involving children in their own care, participants will improve asthma management in the present, but also establish lifelong successful self-management skills. The objective of the proposed study is to pilot test the Improving Asthma Care Together (IMPACT) mobile health application with parent-child dyads. Based on the preliminary data, the central hypothesis is that IMPACT will be effective for delivering a shared asthma management intervention for children and their parents.

primary_outcome.measure: Asthma responsibility questionnaire change from baseline to 8 weeks
primary_outcome.description: 10- items, 5-point scale to report asthma management task responsibility, higher scores indicate higher asthma management responsibility for child.

primary_outcome.measure: Asthma responsibility questionnaire change from 8 to 16 weeks
primary_outcome.description: 10- items, 5-point scale to report asthma management task responsibility, higher scores indicate higher asthma management responsibility for child.

primary_outcome.measure: Asthma management self-efficacy change from baseline to 8 weeks
primary_outcome.description: 13-items (parent) and 12-items (child), 5-point scale assesses asthma self-efficacy, higher scores indicate higher selfefficacy.

primary_outcome.measure: Asthma management self-efficacy change from 8 weeks to 16 weeks
primary_outcome.description: 13-items (parent) and 12-items (child), 5-point scale assesses asthma self-efficacy, higher scores indicate higher selfefficacy.

secondary_outcome.measure: Spirometry - FEV1 change from baseline to 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Spirometry - objective measure of expiratory lung function will be used to evaluate asthma control. Specifically, the FEV1 measure will be used and interpreted according to the national spirometry guideline cutpoints (NAEPP EPR4 report)

secondary_outcome.measure: Spirometry - FEV1 change from 8 weeks to 16 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Spirometry - objective measure of expiratory lung function will be used to evaluate asthma control. Specifically, the FEV1 measure will be used and interpreted according to the national spirometry guideline cutpoints (NAEPP EPR4 report)

Spirometry - objective measure of expiratory lung function will be used to evaluate asthma control. Intervention group will measure weekly via home spirometry device and IMPACT application. Specifically, the FEV1 measure will be used and interpreted according to the national spirometry guideline cutpoints (NAEPP EPR4 report)

secondary_outcome.measure: Spirometry - FEV1/FVC change from baseline to 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Spirometry - objective measure of expiratory lung function will be used to evaluate asthma control. Specifically, the FEV1/FVC measure will be used and interpreted according to the national spirometry guideline cutpoints (NAEPP EPR4 report)

secondary_outcome.measure: Spirometry - FEV1/FVC change from 8 weeks to 16 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Spirometry - objective measure of expiratory lung function will be used to evaluate asthma control. Specifically, the FEV1/FVC measure will be used and interpreted according to the national spirometry guideline cutpoints (NAEPP EPR4 report)

Spirometry - objective measure of expiratory lung function will be used to evaluate asthma control. Intervention group will measure weekly via home spirometry device and IMPACT application. Specifically, the FEV1/FVC measure will be used and interpreted according to the national spirometry guideline cutpoints (NAEPP EPR4 report)

secondary_outcome.measure: Childhood Asthma Control Test change from baseline to 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: 7 total items--3 parent (5-point scale) and 4 child (3-point scale)-- assess asthma control, higher scores indicate better control

secondary_outcome.measure: Childhood Asthma Control Test change from 8 weeks to 16 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: 7 total items--3 parent (5-point scale) and 4 child (3-point scale)-- assess asthma control, higher scores indicate better control

secondary_outcome.measure: Childhood Asthma Quality of Life change from baseline to 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Self-report child-reported asthma quality of life, with higher scores indicating better quality of life. PROMIS Asthma Impact Scale - 8 items, 5-point scale

secondary_outcome.measure: Childhood Asthma Quality of Life change from 8 weeks to 16 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Self-report child-reported asthma quality of life, with higher scores indicating better quality of life. PROMIS Asthma Impact Scale - 8 items, 5-point scale

secondary_outcome.measure: Parent Asthma Quality of Life change from baseline to 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Self-report parent-reported asthma quality of life, with higher scores indicating better quality of life. PROMIS Asthma Impact Scale - 8 items, 5-point scale

secondary_outcome.measure: Parent Asthma Quality of Life change from 8 weeks to 16 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Self-report parent-reported asthma quality of life, with higher scores indicating better quality of life. PROMIS Asthma Impact Scale - 8 items, 5-point scale
4 items using 5-point scale; higher scores indicate higher acceptability.

secondary_outcome.measure: Medication adherence change from baseline to 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Medication Adherence Report Scale for Asthma, 10-items, 5-point scale assessing reported asthma controller medication adherence. Higher scores indicate better adherence.

secondary_outcome.measure: Medication adherence change from 8 weeks to 16 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Medication Adherence Report Scale for Asthma, 10-items, 5-point scale assessing reported asthma controller medication adherence. Higher scores indicate better adherence.

arm_group.description: IMPACT health application and wearable device

intervention.description: IMPACT is a novel health application and wearable device

criteria.textblock:
CHILD Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinician diagnosis of persistent asthma (prescription for daily asthma medication)
- Speak English
PARENT Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years or older
- Child's primary caregiver
- Able to understand and read English
- Reside with the child 50% or more
- Legal guardian who can consent for child to participate
- Have access to a smart phone and reliable home internet access
CHILD Exclusion Criteria:
- Parent report of developmental delay (language < 5 year level)
- Co-morbid cancer, diabetes, ADHD
- Current asthma exacerbation at the time of recruitment

facility.name: University of Washington School of Nursing
